Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the percentage of tax relief going to families making less than $200,000 by stating that "70 percent" of the relief goes to them, while the actual percentage is lower.
Understate: The claim understates the impact of the bill on wealthy households by not considering the changes in corporate and estate taxes, which disproportionately affect high-income earners.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it only cites one chart that focuses on personal income tax changes, without considering other types of taxes affected by the bill.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes the problematic assumption that the percentage of tax relief going to families making less than $200,000 remains constant over time, while it actually decreases in the future.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim fails to consider alternative explanations for the distribution of tax relief, such as the impact of changes in corporate and estate taxes, which could affect the overall distribution.
